verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.comment: This verse introduces a new set of instructions given directly by God, emphasizing the authority and continued revelation to Moses, who mediates God's law to Israel.

verses.text: If anyone sins and acts unfaithfully against the LORD by deceiving his neighbor in a matter of a deposit, a pledge, or by robbery, or has oppressed his neighbor,
verses.comment: Sin is ultimately against God, even if the offense targets a neighbor, highlighting the seriousness and spiritual dimension of all wrongdoing.

verses.text: Or finds something lost and lies about it, or swears falsely—in any of these things a man may do, thus sinning—
verses.comment: The language encompasses various forms of dishonesty, recognizing the gravity of lying and swearing falsely as offenses before God.

verses.text: When he sins and becomes guilty, he must restore what he took by robbery or extorted by oppression, or the deposit entrusted to him, or the lost thing which he found,
verses.comment: Restitution precedes atonement, showing the importance of making things right with others before reconciling with God. This principle is mirrored in the New Testament teaching on reconciliation (see Matt. 5:23-24).

verses.text: Or anything about which he swore falsely—he shall restore it in full, and shall add a fifth to it; he shall give it to the one it belongs to on the day he presents his guilt offering.
verses.comment: The added fifth recognizes justice and ensures genuine repentance for wrongdoing. The timing of restitution with the sacrifice reminds readers of the unity between acts of penance and the sacrificial worship prescribed.

verses.text: And he shall bring to the priest, as his guilt offering to the LORD, a ram without blemish from the flock, according to your assessment, for a guilt offering.
verses.comment: The requirement of a spotless ram prefigures the sinless offering of Christ (see Heb. 9:13-14), showing how God’s justice and mercy meet in the sacrifice.

verses.text: And the priest shall make atonement for him before the LORD, and he will be forgiven for any of the things he may have done to incur guilt.
verses.comment: Forgiveness is granted through the act of atonement mediated by a priest, suggesting the necessity of both confession and sacrificial mediation—reflecting later realities fulfilled through Christ (John 20:23).

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.comment: A new section begins as God again commands Moses, emphasizing continuity in revelation and guidance for worship.

verses.text: Command Aaron and his sons, saying, ‘This is the law of the burnt offering: the burnt offering shall remain on the hearth of the altar all night until morning, and the fire of the altar shall be kept burning on it.
verses.comment: Perpetual fire on the altar symbolizes continual worship and constant presence, foreshadowing ceaseless prayers and offerings to God (Ps. 141:2).

verses.text: And the priest shall put on his linen garments, and put on his linen trousers on his body, and remove the ashes of the burnt offering which the fire has consumed on the altar, and place them beside the altar.
verses.comment: Priestly vestments distinguish their office as sacred, reinforcing the importance of proper ritual and reverence in worship.

verses.text: Then he shall remove his garments, put on other clothes, and carry the ashes outside the camp to a clean place.
verses.comment: Ashes are taken to a clean place, reflecting the need for purity and the removal of sin. The language foreshadows Christ’s sacrifice ‘outside the camp’ (Heb. 13:12).

verses.text: The fire on the altar shall be kept burning; it shall not go out. The priest shall kindle wood on it every morning, lay the burnt offering on it, and burn the fat of the peace offerings on it.
verses.comment: Continuous fire points to perpetual worship required by God and connects to later images of unending prayer and sacrifice seen in Christian liturgy.

verses.text: Fire shall be kept always burning on the altar; it shall never go out.
verses.comment: Repetition for emphasis: perpetual worship demands continual vigilance and reverence in service to God.

verses.text: This is the law of the grain offering: Aaron’s sons shall bring it before the LORD, in front of the altar.
verses.comment: A shift from burnt to grain offerings illustrates the variety and comprehensiveness of Old Testament sacrifices, all ultimately pointing toward fuller worship.

verses.text: He shall take from it a handful of the fine flour of the grain offering, with its oil and all the frankincense that is on the grain offering, and shall burn this as its memorial portion on the altar, a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
verses.comment: A portion is given exclusively to God, symbolizing total dependence and thanksgiving, reminiscent of prayers and offerings made with devotion and reverence.

verses.text: The rest of it Aaron and his sons shall eat. It must be eaten unleavened, in a holy place; they shall eat it in the courtyard of the tent of meeting.
verses.comment: Consumption by the priests connects sacrifice with sacred fellowship, prefiguring the communal meal in later Christian worship. Eating in a holy place points to the spiritual nourishment of those assigned to sacred service (1 Cor. 9:13).

verses.text: It shall not be baked with leaven. I have given it as their portion of my offerings made by fire; it is most holy, as is the sin offering and the guilt offering.
verses.comment: Unleavened bread signifies purity. The designation ‘most holy’ sets apart this food for sacred purposes—a forerunner to holy meals set apart in later worship traditions.

verses.text: Every male among the children of Aaron may eat of it; as a perpetual statute throughout your generations, from the offerings made by fire to the LORD. Everything that touches them must be holy.
verses.comment: Priestly privilege and the importance of passing on sacred duties. Holiness is contagious—a hint toward the sanctifying power of God’s presence in worship.

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.comment: A new directive signals transition to specific ritual practices, underscoring the depth and breadth of instruction.

verses.text: This is the offering that Aaron and his sons shall bring to the LORD on the day when he is anointed: a tenth of an ephah of fine flour as a regular grain offering, half to be offered in the morning and half in the evening.
verses.comment: Morning and evening offerings signify daily dedication—mirroring continual Christian prayer and worship rhythms.

verses.text: It shall be made with oil on a griddle; you shall bring it well mixed and present the baked pieces as a grain offering of a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
verses.comment: The use of oil and the method of preparation highlight both the care given in worship and the symbolism of anointing for service.

verses.text: The priest from among Aaron's sons, who is anointed to succeed him, shall offer it. It is a perpetual statute; the entire grain offering shall be burned.
verses.comment: Priestly succession and perpetual statutes anticipate a continuing and unbroken line of worship leaders—a hint toward later apostolic succession and liturgical continuity.

verses.text: Every grain offering of a priest shall be wholly burned; it shall not be eaten.
verses.comment: Offerings made by priests are set wholly apart for God alone, teaching that some acts of worship are reserved strictly for divine honor, not personal benefit.

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.comment: Another formative command, creating further detail and clarity in the priestly service.

verses.text: Speak to Aaron and his sons, saying, ‘This is the law of the sin offering: In the place where the burnt offering is killed, the sin offering shall be killed before the LORD; it is most holy.
verses.comment: Sin offerings are set apart as ‘most holy.’ Their location on the altar stresses the seriousness of atonement and the demand for purity and reverence in worship.

verses.text: The priest who offers it as a sin offering shall eat it in a holy place, in the courtyard of the tent of meeting.
verses.comment: Priests ate from the offerings in a designated place—this sacred meal foreshadows a participation in holy things through a divinely appointed mediator.

verses.text: Whatever touches its flesh shall be holy; and when any of its blood is sprinkled on a garment, you shall wash that on which it was sprinkled in a holy place.
verses.comment: Contact with the sin offering and its blood sanctifies, showing the transformative power of the sacrificial blood—a type for the sanctifying blood of Christ (Heb. 9:13-14).

verses.text: But the earthen vessel in which it is boiled shall be broken. If it is boiled in a bronze pot, it shall be scoured and rinsed in water.
verses.comment: Purity concerns for vessels echo the separation of holy and common, prefiguring rituals of cleansing—also seen in the washing of baptismal candidates and sacred vessels in sacred worship.

verses.text: Every male among the priests may eat of it; it is most holy.
verses.comment: Priestly access to ‘most holy’ things points to a consecrated priesthood, later developed in the apostolic ministry of the New Covenant.

verses.text: But no sin offering from which any of the blood is brought into the tent of meeting to make atonement in the Holy Place shall be eaten; it shall be burned with fire.
verses.comment: High-level atonement offerings are wholly dedicated to God, prefiguring the ultimate total sacrifice of Christ for the sins of the world (Heb. 13:12).
